summary.p: 43 fol.; Writing surface: paper; Shelfmark: E. H. 224; Qurʾānic Text: Q 51:31-57:29; 5 lines per page; Dimensions: 340 x 485mm; Script style: ṯuluṯ; Date of production: 1268-69 CE.

This entry is based on the catalogue of Fehmi E. Karatay (1888-1968). Currently we do not have access to the images. With exceptions, the catalogue does not contain precise information on the distribution of the text throughout the pages. For this reason, only fol. 1 is given.

Karatay (1962) describes the manuscripts as follows, p. 31: "94 E. H. 224. Kur’andan bir parça. Aharlı krem rengi ve vassaleli kalın kâğıt. 485mm boy ve 340mm eninde 43 yaprak. Sahifede harekeli iri sülüsle 215mm uzunl.[uğunda] 5 satır. Yāḳūt al-Mustaʿṣimī tarafından 667 (1268-69) de yazılmıştır. Y. 1b ve 2a dan orjinal tezhipler alınarak yerine IX. asırda tezhip edilmiş levha konmuştur. Sure başları VII. asır tezhibiyledir. Duraklar ve cetveller yaldız ve reklidir. Miklep şemse ve köşelikli IX. asır İran işi kahve rengi deri cilt. Bu mücellete Zariyat (51) suresinin 31. ayetinden itibaren Ṭūr (52) Nacm (53), Ḳamar (54), Raḥmān (55), Vāḳiʿa (56) ve Ḥadid (57) suresinin sonuna kadar vardır."

This can be translated as follows: "94 E. H. 224. A part of the Qurʾān. Cream-colored thick sized paper with the technique of vaṣṣālī. 43 leaves of 485 mm height and 340 mm width. The text area written in large thuluth with diacritics, [contains] 5 lines measuring 215 mm height. Copied by Yāḳūt al-Mustaʿṣimī in the year 667 (1268-69). Original illuminations in L. 1b and 2a, have been replaced with illuminated plates from the 9th century. Sūra beginnings are decorated in the style of the 7th century. Verse separators and and the rule-borders are in red and gilded. 9th-century Iranian-style brown leather binding with flap (miklep), mandorla (şemse) and cornerpieces. The fragment contains from Q 51:31 (Sūra al- Ḏāriyāt) onwards, Q 52 (Sūra At-Ṭūr), Q 53 (Sūra An-Naǧm), Q 54 (Sūra Al-Qamar), Q 55 (Sūra Ar-Raḥmān), Q 56 (Sūra al-Wāḳiʿa), and up to the end of Q 57 (Sūra Al-Ḥadīd).”
